Determinant of a \(2\times2\) matrix

The determinant of the matrix \(A=\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\) is denoted by \(\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix}\) (note the change from square brackets to vertical lines) and is defined to be the number \(ad-bc\). That is: \[\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = ad-bc.\]

We can use the notation \(\det(A)\) or \(\lvert A \rvert\) to denote the determinant of \(A\). A common symbol used to represent the determinant of a given matrix is \(\Delta.\)
